definition: Yang Zhu (c. 440-360 BC), Chinese philosopher advocating ethical egoism
poplar
surname Yang
surname Zhu
vermilion
cinnabar/see 硃砂|朱砂[zhu1 sha1]

sentences.english: Among the scholars in the pre-Qin period, Yang Zhu seems to be a mysterious figure.
sentences.chinese: 在先秦诸子中，杨朱似乎是一个神秘人物。

sentences.english: Yang Zhu had a younger brother named Yang Bu.

definition: Xun Zi or Hsun Tzu (c. 310-237 BC), Confucian philosopher and author of On learning 勸學|劝学
original name of Mozi 墨子[Mo4 zi3]
Confucius
Mencius (c. 372-c. 289 BC), Confucian philosopher second only to Confucius/book of the same name, one of the classics of Confucianism

Legalist School of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC) founded by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] and Li Si 李斯[Li3 Si1], later adopted by Shang Yang 商鞅[Shang1 Yang1] whose reforms helped establish the supremacy of the Qin Dynasty 秦代[Qin1 dai4] (221-207 BC)
"universal love", principle advocated by Mozi 墨子[Mo4 zi3], stressing that people should care for everyone equally
another name for Laozi 老子[Lao3 zi3]
Confucian school, founded by Confucius 孔子[Kong3 zi3] (551-479 BC) and Mencius 孟子[Meng4 zi3] (c. 372-c. 289 BC)
Han Feizi, book of Legalist Philosophy authored by Han Fei 韓非|韩非[Han2 Fei1] during the Warring States Period (475-220 BC)
Confucian
Confucius (551-479 BC), Chinese thinker and social philosopher, also known as 孔夫子[Kong3 fu1 zi3]
Confucius and Mencius
Mencius 孟子 (c. 372-c. 289), Confucian philosopher
School of Diplomacy of the Warring States Period (475-221 BC) whose leading advocates were Su Qin 蘇秦|苏秦[Su1 Qin2] and Zhang Yi 張儀|张仪[Zhang4 Yi2]
Zhuangzi (369-286 BC), Daoist author
Dong Zhongshu (179-104 BC), philosopher influential in establishing Confucianism as the established system of values of former Han dynasty
